question: A process is a running program in the operating system.
A process cannot exist in multiple states during its execution.
The 'New' state of a process means that it has just been created and is waiting for resources.
A process in the 'Ready' state is currently being executed by the CPU.
The 'Running' state means that the process is actively being executed by the CPU.
A process in the 'Waiting' state is waiting for some resource like user input or file access.
Once a process enters the 'Terminated' state, it can move back to 'Running' state.
The operating system assigns a unique Process ID (PID) to each process.
A Process Control Block (PCB) stores important details about a process.
The PCB does not contain information about the process state.
The program counter in the PCB stores the memory address of the next instruction to be executed.
The CPU registers in the PCB store temporary data like calculations and function calls.
Memory management information in the PCB includes details about RAM usage by a process.
A PCB does not store information about input/output requests made by the process.
Every process has the same priority level in the operating system.
The parent process ID in the PCB helps track child processes created by another process.
The operating system does not require a PCB to manage processes.
Multitasking is possible because the OS efficiently manages multiple processes.
The 'Ready' state means a process is waiting for the CPU to execute it.
A process can move directly from 'Running' to 'New' state.
A process in the 'Waiting' state is waiting for CPU time to execute instructions.
Once a process starts running, it cannot return to the 'Ready' state.
The PCB acts like an identity card for a process in the OS.
The PCB does not store any security-related information.
When you close an application, its process moves to the 'Terminated' state.
The operating system does not need to track process execution states.
Processes in the 'Blocked' state require CPU time to continue execution.
The process priority helps the OS decide which process should be executed first.
A single process can have multiple PCBs assigned to it.
The PCB of a process is removed when the process enters the 'Terminated' state.
A process can remain in the 'New' state indefinitely.
The OS can create a new process without assigning it a Process ID.
The 'Running' state is the only state where a process can execute instructions.
A process in the 'Ready' state is waiting for memory allocation.
The OS can schedule a process to move back and forth between 'Ready' and 'Running' states.
The program counter in the PCB helps resume a paused process.
All processes in an operating system have the same execution time.
Processes in the 'Blocked' state are removed from memory.
Process management ensures efficient execution of multiple processes.
The PCB contains information about the process owner.
A process can never move directly from 'Running' to 'Waiting'.
Each process in the OS is isolated from other processes.
The OS can kill a process before it finishes execution.
The PCB does not contain information about allocated memory resources.
Processes in the 'Ready' state cannot return to the 'New' state.
The process scheduling algorithm decides which process gets CPU time.
Process priority is not considered in CPU scheduling.
A terminated process can be restarted without re-creation.
The OS can handle multiple processes simultaneously.
Every process in an OS shares the same memory space.
